featured_reviews.review_id: If you are blind to good coffee, let sightglass  coffee give you new vision for what a divine cup of coffee tastes like. It was a short line and the coffee roasters were roasting and moving beans like the Willy wonka factory. Breakfast Avocado toast was prepared up in the loft seating area, and after receiving the coffee downstairs- the staircase led the way to a loft flooded with sunshine via the skylight. (See the pictures to give you an idea.) the wooden community tables were beautiful and felt like I was transported out of the streets of SF into the redwood forest outpost. I didn't use the restroom but it had vibes of a frank sinatra movie. Ok, I have said too much, go check it out if you are fortunate enough to visit. And p.S. out pray for the bay.

featured_reviews.review_id: Really nice and cozy cafe with great ambience. There's decent space to sit and work as well. Not as crowded during weekday lunch hours. Their menu was quite interesting with quite a lot of different "flavors" of coffee from mild, medium to strongly caffeinated. Philz coffee is a great coffee chain. It may not have the usual coffee options, especially if you're only interested in a latte or americano. They usually serve their coffee without milk.

featured_reviews.review_id: I have been going to Philz for many years, but I will never return after my experience there this morning. A friend, visiting from outside the United States, was given an undrinkable cup of coffee. When she approached the register to let them know, the woman said in a very brusque tone,  "Too bad. You knew what you were ordering." After trying to pay for another cup of coffee and talking to the manager (equally rude and unhelpful) we left. The lack of basic kindness and poor customer service skills was upsetting and something I'd never experienced before at Philz. In fact, in the past they always seemed willing to go out of their way to make a good cup of coffee! Perhaps there is a general decline in quality, as we noticed that the tables were dirty when we arrived. We left and went to Starbucks --had a lovely time with friendly people behind the counter, good service, and excellent coffee.

featured_reviews.review_id:
I work one block from this location and have been coming here for 18 years.  This morning I bought 2 lbs. of Jacobs and had the girl at the counter give both bags a #5 grind.  When I got back to the clinic where I work I looked at the bags and 1 bag looked much smaller than the other so I weighed them both on a scale at work and, sure enough 1 bag only weighed 3/4 lb.  I don't know what happened.  Not sure if she spilled some but very disappointed.  Felt cheated of 1/4 lb.  At these prices that's over $5.00
worth of coffee.  Don't know if I will return here.  Left a message for the manager but no return call yet.

featured_reviews.review_id:
Nice and small place with great coffee. Tried the iced and hot version of the ginger oat-milk latte. The coffee is smooth, the people are friendly.
Line starts outside and only a few are allowed in at a time. Parking is your typical San Fran nightmare, if there is more than one of you I'd say have them order while you stay with the car.
They ask you don't stay inside but there is an outdoor area available.
Limited options on pastries from what I could see but overall the minimalist approach seems to work, their coffee is great and they rated well for a reason.

featured_reviews.review_id:
This place is inspiring and reminds me of twenty years ago nascent SF coffee. Have been here now on six occasions. The last two visits spurned this review. Small interior with in-dash espresso service units and a custom counter. Style is very evident in all regards including window front tables of wood with metal adornments. Reading material  includes Drift magazines from woebegone days and a few choice zines. Pastries are well above average with enough quality butter in the croissant to warrant a reorder.
The key is the coffee. Espresso. Good espresso with just the right amount of bite to sour to sweet. The cost of doing business here is more than a bargain. The staff is jocular, well read on the science of java, and mechanically expert. Make the trip.

featured_reviews.review_id:
I've heard people talk about Blue Bottle before, so I thought I'd check out one of their  coffee shops while I was in town. I wasn't disappointed.

Although, there weren't fancy syrup flavors for someone like myself who likes sweet flavored lattes, they still had a "sweet latte" on the menu. If you're into sweeter coffee drinks, I'd highly recommend it. Very delicious.

There's even a gorgeous park right around the corner you can hang out in after you get your coffee.

featured_reviews.review_id: It's really amazing how Blue Bottle grew from its Bay Area operation to a global level. Had good experience at every Blue Bottle we've visited in the Bay Area so far. Hoping to see more Blue Bottle and less Starbucks. We ordered their seasonal NOLA iced coffee and the oji pourover. Their seasonal flavor is this orange blossom which adds well to the already delicious creaminess. The oji pourover was expensive but the flavor profile is simply excellent. It was strong yet super smooth. My only problem with Blue Bottle is the price point. I mean coffee is expensive in general if you're not going for the $1 McCafe coffee from Mickey Dees.

featured_reviews.review_id:
Came here with a few friends of mine while visiting the city. Was looking for a breakfast spot with some good coffee, and we ended up here at Beanstalk.

The Food: I went with a "Lox Bagel" and a "Dirty Chai Latte". The Lox bagel was good! Had a good amount of lox on the bagel, with plenty of greens to pair it with. I enjoyed it a lot. The Dirty Chai Latte was delicious as well. That Chai flavor was well there and it wasn't too sweet.

The Service: Service was good. Staff were friendly. This place can get really busy in the morning, so come early or be prepared to wait for a bit. However, the food/drinks do come out in a timely manner.

The Atmosphere: This spot is quite small. Not that many places to sit here, so most of the time I saw people just ordering their foods to go.

Overall, a 4/5. Very good breakfast spot to grab yourself a bagel/sandwich and some coffee. I'd recommend giving this place a try.

featured_reviews.review_id:
This place was so close to my hotel and I discovered it on my last day.

I ordered the funky town and was immediately sad I didn't order someone on a cragel (croissant and bagel) but after eating my sandwich that feeling went right out the window. I also got a dirty chai, they had alternative milk options. And a cookie I'm saving for later.

Super cute, staff was friendly and helpful. They worked really well together taking turns taking orders, making beverages. They communicated well too and I'm sure that's helpful working in that small space.

I wish I had decided to eat there because they have a nice indoor space but also a few outdoor options.

Glad I discovered this place on my last day because I think I would have found a reason to go here everyday.

featured_reviews.review_id:
We really liked the Cranberry Turkey and Egg Salad sandwiches- good crust on the bread, the right ratio between ingredients and decent sized portions.

The banana bread was also really good, moist and not too sweet.

The coffee was decent (we got espresso and capuccino), but needs a little bit of extra work to be called a specialty coffee (temperature was too high and and flavour not as strong).

Service was nice and fast, would definitely come back for the food!

featured_reviews.review_id: Solid caffe latte with just the right combination of espresso notes, milk and crema. I love places that roast their own beans and enjoyed viewing the roaster on site while breathing in the rich aromas of roasted coffee beans. Service was average though the barista did share he was a highly satisfied regular patron before taking the job. That's always a good sign. What makes this establishment special is a secluded courtyard in the back that allows one to bask in the sun while enjoying private space - right in the heart of busy, industrial SoMa district. Chart a course to Sextant and your sails will be filled.

It is right up there with the best elsewhere in the world (Australia, Italy, other European countries). It went well with a really good cinnamon scroll. featured_reviews.review_id: Hard to get good coffee in SF, and this place is no exception. Don't come here if you want light roast delight. Overall... Don't bother to come.

featured_reviews.review_id:
This review is a long time coming. Aside from this being the best coffee in the city, the staff at the Divisadero location is 2nd to none! I have been regularly visiting this location for the past 3 years and the folks that work here are phenomenal in every sense of the word. The one suggestion I have for the owners is ventilation. The location is great with beautiful light, however, this sun-drenched location is in need of ventilation upgrades to support staff and patrons alike.  It can heat up like an oven in there at times, and I would love to see the ventilation improved on behalf of the good folks working hard to deliver the best coffee and service in the city.

Bravo Sightglass staff, you are the best!!!

I was in the city to do some shopping and felt a need to eat something good. A friend recommended this small cafe and a quick few minutes walk from the city center later, I'm loving it!!

I got their roast beef sandwich (with caramelized onions, home made rosemary sauce with a touch of garlic, arugula dresses with our own honey vinaigrette and balsamic sauces, melted Swiss cheese on well toasted crispy ciabatta)!
I had the one thing and currently is on my top sandwiches in the city.

Small but adorable cafe with a good amount of indoor and outdoor seating. Menu also includes breakfast items, baked goods, and a selection of coffee beverages.

Will definitely be back to try other items!

featured_reviews.review_id:
I had the best Salmon Toast and Avocado Toast here with a stellar espresso. (i am a coffee snob).
The salmon was so fresh and the cheese was to die for. Their avocado toast is epic and the bread starts crunchy and melts in your mouth.
I was rebooked twice on my trans-pacific flight and was too exhausted to do anything but eat and have coffee. The person taking my order was very patient. He let me put in my airline voucher details (card number etc) for each order and the food was served immediately.
The atmosphere is really cute and full of plants and nice high stools. Definitely a gem of a place with decent prices.

featured_reviews.review_id: I'm a 23 y/o senior here at IU, and visited this location yesterday to study for a very difficult exam. After being seated for less than 20 minutes, the "assistant manager" came up to me, headphones on and deep in studying, to ask if I was going to buy something...Concentration ruined, ugh...I was taken aback. I always spend money when I go to a cafe, but shame on me for not doing so the second I walked in the door I suppose... Maybe this location has an issue with loitering, due to its close proximity to the dorms? This could also explain the employees overall attitude. I informed her that yes, I was going to purchase a drink and a snack; Nevertheless, it was not a tactful or pleasant interaction, and I was unhappy to be interrupted in the middle of my work for what I consider an insulting reason...Does every customer receive this shakedown? Is it so uncommon to find a seat before going to the counter, that it warranted confrontation? Or possibly, am I just special? :) I'm no rookie to coffee shops, I've studied for hours prior to getting coffee and have never experienced this treatment anywhere. If I do return to this location, I'll buy my coffee immediately, to avoid interruption and being mistaken for a loiterer...Overall, the place left a bad taste in my mouth, which certainly wasn't from the coffee or delicious baked goods...It's a shame, because I love the other two Soma's in B-Town, and this one is the closest to my apartment. But alas, employees make-or-break the coffee-shop experience, and because of this, I will be going elsewhere in the future.

featured_reviews.review_id:
Soma is one of my favorite cafe in Bloomington! They have multiple locations in town including one near Sample Gate. This location is perfect for music school students who's seeking some fresh after hours of practicing. The cafe doesn't have seats inside currently but has some outdoor seating. They also have a few parking spots available.
If you'd like to try some special flavor, don't miss the Razz-Ma-Tazz (Rasberry +dark chocolate latte)! (Option to add cream on the top for ice one)
They also sell reusable straws, get one here if you're beverage lover like me but don't wanna feel guilty to produce waste!

featured_reviews.review_id: Just like the other location on Market, the staff at the 2nd Street location are friendly. Don't be afraid to ask questions. The taste is consistent from one location to another. By the way, Breve drinks are made with Half & Half. If you like drinks that are creamier/have more milk, ask for Breve. The base of my drink is the Scratch Caramel Latte, but it would be too long to say Scratch every time.  You can get it hot or iced.

I'm so glad I don't have to go all the way to the sunset for andytown anymore! And even more glad there is another third wave option other than Nestle's Blue Bottle. This location is everything - right on the Transbay Park so it's a perfect spot to start your morning before work.

I was surprised to see when we got here that Andytown is on the 7th floor of the building, on the same level as Salesforce park. Order ahead experience was seamless and easy.

I Like this place but it's frustrating that they don't post an accurate schedule or keep to their posted hours.  I tried to go twice this week during hours when their website and their sign outside says they should be open, and they were closed with no explanation or notes on their website.  Consistency is important to me in a coffee place if I'm going to be a regular.  That said, food and drink quality are great if they're actually open.

Edit to reply to owner:  having to close due to health reasons is understandable but next time please at least post a sign.  Your reply says back to normal hours "next week" but I have no idea what that means since you didn't include a date.  Please be specific so people can plan their day!!  We need to know when you're open and when you're not!!

Spent 20 mins walking here from my office since it was 1pm and Google Maps hours says they're open until 2pm. Arrived around 1:25pm and was impolitely told they've already closed for the day. No apology or anything. Things come up and that's fine but a more polite "hey, sorry but we have to close early today, maybe check out X other spot nearby" would've been appreciated instead of the response I got.

Ended up at a shop nearby with a name that rhymes with boat and enjoyed my coffee there.

featured_reviews.review_id:
Definitely interesting and difference, compared to other brand coffee. This place serves authentic Yemen, which is very very unique and fascinating.
However, I can't get use to the complex taste from the way their brew coffee (boiling large chunks), and from spices (lots of them, you can't image the variety).
That said, not for me doesn't mean this is not good. Four start just for its existence.

This is a new ethnic cafe transporting one to Arabia with their aromatic tea, coffee, and pastries!! Staff is friendly and the atmosphere is excellent. You can find a seat at the back and have a nice corner to yourself and stare out the street, or you can sit outside.

featured_reviews.review_id:
We absolutely love the honeycomb latte and the rose latte!

The honeycomb gradually melts into the coffee making a lightly sweet drink (I loved it even though I usually don't prefer sweet coffees). The rose latte is definitely sweeter of the two but we appreciated how strong the rose flavor was.

We have also tried the banana bread here which was pretty solid (especially when heated up) but was very expensive for the size so probably wouldn't get it again. Also there isn't much seating other than an outdoor bench so expect to take your coffee to-go!

Overall, love the coffee here and will definitely be coming back!!

featured_reviews.review_id: The cutest little coffee shop that quickly became a go to spot for afternoon caffeine fix with my coworkers. featured_reviews.review_id: This Bluestone Lane cafe is located inside the same building as the Emblem Hotel. It is accessible through a separate door. The cafe is small with limited opportunity to sit down and drink your coffee there. When the weather permits there is outdoor seating available, but there are only a few tables available, and they are right on the sidewalk of Sutter Street, so it can be noisy. The staff at this Bluestone Lane cafe was very accommodating, knowledgeable, and helpful. We enjoyed being in the cafe and the drinks were delivered quite quickly. We will definitely come back to this cafe.

featured_reviews.review_id:
So happy a Haraz coffee house has opened in SF! I went to the original one in Michigan and was floored at how great theirs drinks were and the commitment to perfection they have in everything that they do.

This location is no different. Their drinks are so tasty. The Mofawer is so tasty and their Dragonfruit drink is also so refreshing and flavorful.

They have a lot of seats, are open late, and have a great environment for either grinding through some work on your computer or meeting friends for a coffee.

I will be back!

featured_reviews.review_id:
This is a new coffee place at Franklin and Bush, a busy intersection.  This is the second coffee place that's been there in the last few years.  I've been in a couple of times, the first for some pastries, the second for a large black coffee.

First visit for pastries - they have an interesting selection of sweets.  I bought a blueberry muffin and a chocolate hazelnut muffin on the first visit.  The blueberry was mediocre, but the chocolate hazelnut was a nice surprise.  Together, before tax, it was just shy of $12 for the two.

Second visit was just for some coffee.  Plain, black, large.  I thought it would be quick, but it wasn't.  They brew each cup individually, kind of like Vietnamese coffee, so this took longer than I was expecting.  I'm not sure how they manage this if it's busy, but I was not in a rush.  I was a little disappointed that it wasn't a full cup.  Even after adding some cream, there was quite a bit of room left.  The flavor of the coffee reminded me of some of the stronger Turkish coffees I've had.  Price was $6.50, which seemed a little pricey for a not quite full cup of drip coffee.

The guys behind the counter are very nice and helpful.  And, I'm not sure if they have wifi (I assume so), but it seems like a nice neighborhood place to sit and maybe work on the computer or read a book or chat with a friend.  Also, both times, I came in from just having walked my dog, and they didn't seem to have a problem with that.  I wasn't staying, so not sure if dogs are actually allowed.

Overall, I think that the place has potential and I hope that they can stand the test of time!  Having a faster alternative for a standard, black drip coffee would be worth investigating for them.  That corner is a pick up spot for travelers hopping on buses, and if they want a quick coffee, they wouldn't get it there, so maybe offering something a little less artisanal, but quicker, a la Pete's Coffee, would be a good idea!

featured_reviews.review_id:
The former Klutch Coffee shop has been transformed into Hraz Coffee, a cafe focused on Yemeni coffee. According to the cashier, Yemen was the source of coffee in the 1900s (he mentioned a place called Mocca :)
The pastry case was super tempting so I bought a pistachio cheesecake which they have customed made (like all their desserts). The cheesecake was smooth with a light pistachio flavor and chunks of pistachio nuts. Not overly sweet which is good. The graham cracker crust was firm.
I have to say the Mediterranean savories (phyllo based pies) and sweets (honey cream stuffed bread, cakes, baklava and more) that were on display were impressive.
Only opened 2 weeks!
Love the chill music, the wall art that transport me to a cafe in the eastern Mediterranean or Africa.
This cafe is definitely a relaxing spot. Convenient to CPMC Van Ness, Cathedral Hill, within a short walk to Japantown and one block off Van Ness.
I've got to return to try a beverage!

Cute new shop serving Yemen style coffee! Love the unique menu items. I got the Rada'ai coffee - a sweet ginger cardamom coffee and my husband got the Saffron Adeni - a hot spiced chai tea.

TBH, service was very slow! It took about 20 minutes to get our two drinks with only two other groups who ordered before us. But benefit of the doubt, they've literally only been open for about a week, so they're probably still dialing in their staff, recipes, and techniques!

Ambiance is quiet and calm. Great space to bring a laptop and get some work done, or sit down with a good book. Love the eclectic style of the cafe too.

Overall, excited to come back and try something else!

I decided a Chicken Sandwich over the salmon sandwich or BLT. The French fries were hot and perfect and I really enjoyed the food. Server was very nice and I'm sure I'll try the coffee or Latte in a few hours. Great design with the seating and bookshelves.

featured_reviews.review_id: Really comfy seats with plenty of outlets which is a big plus!!! Great to do work at. However, it was a bit pricy. $7 for a small matcha!! The wifi is also complimentary and you don't need a password to get in. Overall, I might return but it definitely is a bit out of my budget.
